body: Slipped Discs Fell Nathan Lane The London production of ''The Producers'' has lost Nathan Lane, below. Suffering from two slipped discs, he has withdrawn from his remaining appearances as the conniving producer Max Bialystock, the BBC reported. In November, Mr. Lane stepped into the production on short notice after Richard Dreyfuss, citing recent
title: Arts, Briefly

body: With the last class complete at P.S. 308 in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, so many basketball players have filled the school's tiny gymnasium that there is barely space to bounce a ball. title: Bringing Some Order to Games That City's Young Students Play

body: THE 33 houses of the tiny Vinegar Hill Historic District, on the East River east of Dumbo in Brooklyn, are like a small settlement out on the prairie, isolated not by amber waves of grain but by a swath of surrounding power plants, highways and housing projects. title: STREETSCAPES/Brooklyn; A Piquant Journey Through Vinegar Hill

body: EVERY few weeks Donna Leftwich drives from her Larchmont home to meet her son, Jim, here at the movies. title: Picture-House-Proud

title: SQUARE FEET/Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn; Transforming an Unappealing Street

author: George Sarrinikolaou is the author of ''Facing Athens: Encounters With the Modern City.''
body: IMMIGRATING to New York from Athens, my father promised, would make us rich. As a boy, I never fully believed him. Still, I welcomed the fantasy, not so much because I yearned for more toys or better food than my working-class parents provided me in Greece, but so that they might stop fighting. The lack of money was a nightly topic for my parents
title: THE NEXT WAVE; 'A Lifetime Of Living Half a Life'

body: Everyone understands that pop entertainment relies on formulas. One kind of movie is a hit; three clones appear within months. Experimental art is no different. title: THEATER REVIEW; When Faust Gets Ahold of a Rock 'n' Roll Lyric Book

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Officer's Gun Hurts Youth

title: $25 AND UNDER; The Danube Flows in Brooklyn

body: Virginia Eden sat at her living room table, cane hooked over the arm of her chair, fingering the yellowing photographs of herself as a young woman. Each picture is from a time when her body moved as she wished, when it jitterbugged and danced the Latin Hustle, and swam in the Atlantic Ocean at Coney Island with her best friend, Annette Cappello.

body: Whose hands made this wall, the history books do not tell. Faceless lunch-pail carriers stacked these bricks and stones, men made briefly strong with twice-daily naval rations of grog, a roughly even mixture of water and rum. title: City's Infant Mortality Rate Jumped by 8 Percent in 2003

body: The Swirls Of Chagall The figures in Chagall's paintings often look whimsically adrift, floating like balloons that a spring breeze has tugged from a child's hand. title: FAMILY FARE

title: Fellow Patient Charged in Nursing Home Rape

body: Former M.T.A. Chief Is Multi-Tasking at 70 ''Are you kidding?'' Richard Ravitch said last week when asked whether he was thinking of retiring. Actually, it was more like, ''Are you kidding!!'' body: Marty Markowitz, Brooklyn's head cheerleader, was still riding a wave of euphoria, one day after the developer Bruce C. Ratner had won the bidding for the New Jersey Nets with plans to install them in a new home near downtown Brooklyn. ''It's exciting,'' said Mr. Markowitz, the borough president. ''It puts Brooklyn back in the big leagues.'' But
title: Bid for a Brooklyn Sports Complex Faces Challenges From All Sides

body: UNTIL now, basketball in Brooklyn mostly meant schoolyard courts or the high school gyms where teenagers learned to shoot and pass, to dunk and defend. You could dream about playing for the Knicks at the Garden, but if you had big-time talent, you had to go away to a college out there in the sticks where you knew you would feel like a stranger.
title: Sports of The Times; Brooklyn Crosses Bridge Back Into the Big Time

body: To the Editor: As a fourth-generation Brooklynite and a proud graduate of P.S. 119, I take exception to the statement that Brooklyn is being revived by chic new restaurants in Fort Greene, artists' lofts in Williamburg and the transformation of derelict factory buildings into million-dollar condominiums in Dumbo (front page, Jan. 16). The essence
title: The Brooklyn I Love

body: IF ever there was a telltale sign of what it means to be the New Jersey Nets, it has come these last few weeks, from the moment Isiah Thomas became the Knicks' new head chef and began making chicken salad at Madison Square Garden. Remember that storm between Jason Kidd and Byron Scott? Alonzo Mourning's brave struggle for survival? The fluid,
title: Sports of The Times; If Stern Is Rooting, It Must Be for Brooklyn

body: The revival of Brooklyn has been painfully slow, an effort eked out neighborhood by neighborhood, with chic new restaurants in Fort Greene, artists' lofts in Williamsburg, new businesses in industrial Red Hook and the transformation of derelict factory buildings into million-dollar condominiums in an area with the unlikely name of Dumbo. But the
title: Yo, Dodgers? No Way! Brooklyn Is Betting on the Nets for Revival
